Regarding the "mirrors reverse along axes perpendicular to their surfaces" statement with the hand either moving sideways or flipping backwards, that's an incorrect presentation of what needs to happen in order for the reversing to seem upside-down.

The issue is with the flawed perception people have of what's going on with the mirroring process:

All a mirror does is reflecting the photons back while keeping their spatial alignment with each other the same, meaning light from an object's right (reflected perpendicularly) returns to the right; from an object's upper side return to the upper side, etc. Your perception of what axis is being flipped depends on how are you used to rotate 180° in this world.

Let's say people could only rotate around the X axis, and thus could only face each other by having a feet-vs-head alignment rather than a righthand-vs-lefthand alignment; that would mean you would only be familiar with looking at other people's front when their face is at the bottom of your field of vision. If you would look at yourself in the mirror in such a world what you would experience is your body's front looking upside-down-reversed compared to how other people see you rather than left-right-reversed, because you would see your face up in your field of vision rather than your feet.

And if people could only rotate around the Z axis and thus could see other people's back, your perception of your mirrored self would be that it's front-back-reversed.

I saw a video recently that said that mirrors don’t reverse the reflection “left to right” but “back to front”. It started from the question of why mirrors reflect left to right but not bottom to top. Even many educated people will tell you that it is because your eyes are set horizontally but if you think about it you can close one eye and things still aren’t reversed up and down.

Imagine if you hold a gloved hand palm down towards a mirror. Imagine that you peel the glove off so the wrist was farther away than your fingers. The back has become the front. It would now be oriented to fit on the reflected hand. We interpret the hand and glove as being reversed left to right because that explanation seems right and has good predictive value (if you ignore the not reversing up and down issue). But it is really a front to back reversal. When you turn a sign toward a mirror and see it reversed, the mirror didn’t reverse the letters left to right, you did when you turned it towards the mirror. The mirror just made the side pointing away from you become the side pointing towards you.

The reflected image is not twice smaller, the size decrease is. Just put your hand, for example, 4 inches away from a mirror and you'll see it's almost the same. If you look at your hand in one position and then put it a little further away so the real image would look smaller to you by 20% then the image in the mirror would look 36% smaller then the immage of your hand in first position (0.8^2 = 0.64,  1 - 0.64 = 36) because the light would have to go twice the distance. The difference between real image of something 0.5 inches away from an eye and the image of the same something 4 inches away is much bigger then the difference between 4 inches and 7.5 inches. The further away is the object the slower it would seemingly decrease in it's size. So the images in mirrors are indeed smaller, but the difference depends on how far from the mirror the object is.

3:09 Wow, I've never seen Vsauce get something so blatantly wrong before. He says: "Mirrors reverse along axis perpendicular to their surfaces, like left and right. They don't also [...] reverse up and down, because those directions are parallel to the [mirror] surface."
But think about it! Both up/down and left/right are actually parallel to the surface, so this is clearly the wrong explanation for why our mirror image appears reversed in left/right but apparently not reversed in the up/down direction. Left and right are perpendicular to the mirror surface, but up and down are parallel? No dude, that doesn't have any relation to what's going on. In fact I don't even know what you think you meant by that. A mirror doesn't reverse an image left/right or up/down or diagonally. It reverses the image back to front. Here's an experiment that illustrates this.

Paint your left hand red and your right hand blue. Now press both hands on a mirror. Actually, a window would be better. As you look at your reflection in the glass, you see the red handprint on your left and the blue handprint on your right, same as where your real hands are. Now without washing your hands, go around and look through the window from the other side, the way other people see you. Your red hand is now where the blue handprint is, and your blue hand is where the red handprint is. This is because you are looking at the handprints from the back instead of the front. This is what a mirror does - it reverses the image front to back.

What about the up/down thing though? Try repeating the experiment lying on your left side. Pressing your hands on the glass makes a left (red) handprint by the floor and a right (blue) handprint higher up. Now go around, lie on your right side like someone would be facing you, and look back through the window. Your blue right hand is now by the floor where the red handprint is, and your red left hand is up in the air where the blue handprint is. So yes, it does seem like an up/down reversal. But the same reversal will happen if you do the experiment propped up diagonally. The difference is always that you're looking at the image from different sides of the glass, seeing it from the front and from the back.

That's what a mirror does - it reverses the image from front to back.

It's amazing how many people don't understand how mirrors work, and Vsauce is even more confused than most. 3:10 "mirrors reverse along axes perpendicular to their surfaces like left and right" (holds hand edge-on to the mirror to illustrate left and right). "They don't also flip things upside down, they don't also reverse up and down because those directions are parallel to the surface of the mirror" (holds hand parallel to the mirror to illustrate up and down). Of course, you could have held your hand edge-on to the mirror while demonstrating up and down too. The description was nonsensical and wrong. It's true that a mirror reverses the axis perpendicular to its surface, but there is only one direction that is perpendicular, and that's "in and out".

Hold up an arrow pointing left to the mirror. The reflection in the mirror is also pointing to your left. Nothing is reversed. Instead of the arrow, hold out your left arm. The arm that is held out in the mirror is also on your left. Yes, it's the mirror person's "right arm" but that's only if you imagine the mirror person as a real person facing the opposite direction to you, as if you walked around the back of the mirror, flipped around, and are now facing out. But you didn't. And even if you did, you could just as easily (well, not quite as easily) have gotten round the back by clambering over the top and flipping vertically. Then up and down would be reversed. In short, the impression of left-right reversal is just a mistake we make by thinking of the image as "real".

But what about mirror writing? Yeah, same thing. When you hold up a page of writing to the mirror it's not the mirror that flipped it. Think about it. You flipped it in order to hold it up. If you hadn't flipped it, it wouldn't be flipped in the mirror ... https://laughingsquid.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Why-Do-Mirrors-Flip-Words.png

No, a mirror doesn't "reverse" you or your image. That's a myth. You're just facing the other way.

When someone looks at your face, they are standing in the opposite direction to you. When you use a mirror, you are looking in the same direction as yourself (obviously!).

Try this. Write a word on thin paper. Hold it in front of a mirror. Notice it seems backward. That's because you're looking at it with the paper turned round backwards. Now, without moving your arms, take the paper over to a source of light, a window or lamp. Look at the now partly-transparent paper. The word is backwards, right? Because you're looking at it from the back!

It's not obvious til you're told about it, unless you're smart enough to work it out for yourself. But up until you're falsely told that mirrors reverse an image, you wouldn't have thought such a thing anyway. I raise my arm on the right of me, and the arm on my right side in the mirror also raises. It's not HIS right side, my reflection, but I'm not him, I'm me. He's facing the other way. It's definitely the same hand on the same side though, I could put an X on it if I wanted to prove that.

If you called it my "west" arm, assuming it's to the west of my head, then this confusion wouldn't happen, both me and my reflection's western arms would be waving. But left and right aren't fixed directions, they depend... which way you're facing!

Mirrors do not reverse images, this is nonsense caused by people considering the view from the image, not from themselves. Which is of course nonsense, the image isn't real. They even talk about "real" and "virtual" images when they teach mirrors at school, but miss out the obvious truth! So stop spreading lies!

Of course this all applies to ordinary flat mirrors. Curved ones do all sorts of weird stuff.

Mirrors do NOT 'flip things right-to-left'. If you write on a sheet of paper with a thick marker (so you can make it out from the back of the sheet of paper, i.e. through the sheet.) and hold it up to a mirror, you will see that the writing is already reversed from your viewpoint of being behind the paper. The mirror reflects the writing exactly as it appears, but you are looking from behind the sheet, not the front like normal.

He's gotten one thing wrong here... He says mirrors don't flip things upside down, just left to right.  The truth is, they don't flip things at all.  The reason left and right seem to have flipped is because you rotated to the left or right to face the mirror.  There is another way to face the mirror (when you are first facing away from it) and that is to roll backwards, upside down on your head.  You will now be facing the mirror, left and right will be preserved, and your image will be upside down.

Such an infuriating explanation of how mirrors flip, it's true that mirrors flip perpendicular axes, but left-right isn't perpendicular, just like up-down.
The only perpendicular axis is front-back which is how mirrors flip.
The reason it feels like they flip left-right is because a human face flipped front-back looks much closer to a left-right flip than an up-down flip.
To prove it try cutting out some non-symmetrical letters in cardboard like a capital 'L' and seeing what they look like in a mirror, it'll look as if it hasn't been flipped at all because a front-back flip doesn't change how it looks.

The thing I wonder about is the fact that the images in a mirror have a 3-D appearance all around. This, despite the fact the image is on a 2 dimensional surface. It seems like this could be used to make a 3-D video display. All one would have to do is recreate how the image is actually formed on the mirror. That is to say, cause light emitted to from the screen to follow the same paths as reflected photons would take when they bounce off the reflective surface. If a reflected image is created by the angle photons are reflected, could it not be possible to cause a light source to emit a photon in the same way without the need for a photon bouncing off the thing being viewed in the mirror and reflected back again? Sort of cutting out the middle man.

To be, or not to be: that is the question:
Whether ’tis nobler in the mind to suffer
The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune,
Or to take arms against a sea of troubles,
And by opposing end them? To die: to sleep;
No more; and by a sleep to say we end
The heart-ache and the thousand natural shocks
That flesh is heir to, ’tis a consummation
Devoutly to be wish’d. To die, to sleep;
To sleep: perchance to dream: ay, there’s the rub;
For in that sleep of death what dreams may come
When we have shuffled off this mortal coil,
Must give us pause: there’s the respect
That makes calamity of so long life;
For who would bear the whips and scorns of time,
The oppressor’s wrong, the proud man’s contumely,
The pangs of despised love, the law’s delay,
The insolence of office and the spurns
That patient merit of the unworthy takes,
When he himself might his quietus make
With a bare bodkin? who would fardels bear,
To grunt and sweat under a weary life,
But that the dread of something after death,
The undiscover’d country from whose bourn
No traveller returns, puzzles the will
And makes us rather bear those ills we have
Than fly to others that we know not of?
Thus conscience does make cowards of us all;
And thus the native hue of resolution
Is sicklied o’er with the pale cast of thought,
And enterprises of great pith and moment
With this regard their currents turn awry,
And lose the name of action.–Soft you now!
The fair Ophelia! Nymph, in thy orisons
Be all my sins remember’d.

A mirror is an object that reflects light in such a way that, for incident light in some range of wavelengths, the reflected light preserves many or most of the detailed physical characteristics of the original light, called specular reflection. This is different from other light-reflecting objects that do not preserve much of the original wave signal other than color and diffuse reflected light, such as flat-white paint.

The most familiar type of mirror is the plane mirror, which has a flat surface. Curved mirrors are also used, to produce magnified or diminished images or focus light or simply distort the reflected image.

Mirrors are commonly used for personal grooming, viewing oneself (where they are also called looking-glasses), viewing the area behind and on the sides on motor vehicles while driving, for decoration, and architecture. They are often used by technicians, mechanics and dentists for viewing around and behind obstructions. Mirrors are also used in scientific apparatus such as telescopes and lasers, cameras, and industrial machinery. Most mirrors are designed for visible light; however, mirrors designed for other wavelengths of electromagnetic radiation are also used.

The answer to the question at 4:20 is wrong, or ambiguous at best.
How big is your reflection to you?
Does it depend on how far away you are from the mirror? Michael said it doesn't, but it really depends on how you interpret the question. The most usual interpretation is something like "How big does your reflection appear from your perspective?" If that's the question being asked, then it definitely does depend on your distance from the mirror.
As you get further away from the mirror, the image gets smaller, as we all know. But also as we move further away from the mirror, our view of the mirror itself also gets smaller. These two things happen at the same rate, and so cancel each other out, which is how Michael got the result he arrived at.
Of course, the question Michael answered was "How big is your reflected image (if it were a real object) compared to the real you?"

Gadzooks! Ok, I've wondered about this hypothetical scenario since I was a little kid. I am absolutely not satisfied with this description of what you would see. Here's why: because of the constant curve, objects placed within the sphere would be reflected in most every part of the sphere. Looking ahead, you would be reflected, looking to the sides, you would be reflected, looking up/down you would be reflected; looking in any direction you would be reflected, and these reflections would need to cancel each other out somehow since they would all overlap.  I'm almost certain his explanation for what you would see falls short of the reality. I mean, for starters, he asserts that from the center, your reflected face would fill your field of view. How can this possibly be correct when every other part of you would be reflected as well?  Someone please build a room sized sphere with a mirror inside! Maybe I will one day. I also feel cheated that he spent less than half the video on the title topic and the rest just lumping in other mirror ideas. So... thanks for addressing a lifelong curiosity of mine that I've never heard anyone else address before, but I heavily doubt the accuracy of your conjectural conclusion.

This is the first time i disagree with vsauce, mirrors don't flip horizontally, they flip front to back, we are tricked into thinking it has fliped horizontally but as vsauce says, mirror reflexions are orthogonal, meaning the light hits in the same spots no matter how far you are, but the reflexion size is due to the way our eyes sees, which is in perspective projection (images come in cones wich forms an angle), unlike orthogonal where light rays travel parallel to each other and perpendicular to an imaginary plane where the image is received.

But your right hand in the mirror is still on the right side of the mirror from your perspective due to this orthogonal projection, a trully horizontal flip will make your right arm appear on the left side of the mirror, think of it like you were turned your front to your back, that makes sense right?

Flat mirrors don't reverse...They reflect.
It looks reversed but only because of our tendency to apply ourselves to the image we see.
It just "looks" reversed. But raise your left hand and in the mirror, the hand on the left side will raise.
And its still your left hand reflected back exactly as it is, pixel for pixel.
In a way you could look at it as seeing your front-side from behind. ;)
It only looks reversed to you because the mirror doesn't reverse it.
If you were to physically be able to turn around to face yourself however, That would be a reversal.

I don't know what you're getting at with your explanation of perpendicular vs parallel flipping. Both horizontal and vertical lines can be either perpendicular or parallel to the surface of a standing mirror, we have 3 dimensions of space to work with here. I don't see how mirrors flip anything at all. Maybe if you try to consider yourself as a cohesive unit with a rotational axis it can look like something is flipping, but you're not that. We are collections of things, the mirror does not recognize you as an object then rotate that object around an axis, it simply reflects each part of you separately. I mean a mirror clearly does front to back reflection exclusively, it has no meaningful orientation other than that. I guess the real illusion here is that bodies are single units and not just a continuous clump of matter and energy, that seems to be whats confusing people

Mirrors don't reverse left and right, they flip front and back. If you write a word on a transparent piece of plastic or glass, hold it out in front of you with it between you and a mirror such that you can correctly read what you're holding, the version in the mirror will also read correctly.

On the "light heating you up until y'er cooked" bit: there's a far simpler way of understanding why this would never happen. In order to "cook" the thing inside your mirror-sphere, you need to keep adding energy from some source. Even if you could get a photon, or photons, to retain nearly all its energy, it would still be nowhere near enough to cook anything. In fact, the total amount of energy stored in the batteries of your average flashlight, is nowhere near enough to provide you with a nice medium-rare delectable hunk of prime Argentine beef filet mignon.

your explenation for why the mirror images gets "reversed" in the horizontal direction and the vertical direction is false though. a plane has to vectors defining it, and the vertical direction is just as paralell to the surface as the horizontal. The reason its not "reversed" is because mirrors dont actually "reverse" the image, they send the light back from where it came, its not the image thats reversed its the perspective of the viewer that is changed. If you have a pimple on your left cheek, it will be on your right cheek in a onlookers frame of reference, in the mirror however you will se from your own reference frame and it will appear on the left cheek. Its simply a matter of where you are when you are watching the light relative to the thing youre watching. Thats why up remains to be up, because up remains up regardless of wether youre watching the light before or after the reflextion.

2:26 The spherical mirror 'rendition' is very poor for Vsauce. Within the first few head diameters you could recognize yourself, but soon you would see an exploding head as light from your ears, forehead, & chin would gradually return from the entire visible mirror. Inversion is not visible until you are near the 'back' wall and you can separate the circularly distorted, multiple reflection 'yous' from the antipodal you.
3:18 Flat mirrors don't reverse nor invert! You look right to see your right half, left to your left half, up to your upper body, down to your lower body. Where is the 'reversal'? The reversal is in your head!
3:75 You can see your companion's view of you with a corner mirror as in a gym or dance studio or even some well designed bathrooms.
4:11 The imperfect pangraph (attempt to use all the letters of the alphabet only once) should be replaced by the less commonly understood but perfect pangraph invented by Robert L Birch, "Qwm fjord quiz vext glyphs bank." (The bay valley test confused the cryptographers group.)
5:10 Drawing on the mirror, is only drawing in the 'air' halfway toward your mirror self. The reason for why your image appears flipped left-right in a mirror is not parallel and perpendicular axes. (Left-right is just as parallel to the mirror's surface as top-bottom.) A mirror only flips things in the depth axis. Horizontally and vertically, it shows you everything right where it really is. The illusion comes from the fact that you're not looking at another person - whose left hand side would be on your right hand side - but at yourself - so your right hand side is, well, on your right hand side.
For a better explanation than my comment, check out Physics Girl's video "Why do mirrors flip horizontally (but not vertically)?".

3:09 If we're talking about a mirror in a typical orientation, both the left/right and up/down axes are parallel to the surface of the mirror. Only the forward/backward axis is perpendicular to the mirror (normal to the mirror, if we're being pedantic). The "fact" that mirrors preserve up/down and reverse left/right is just an artifact of how our minds interpreting the image. It's just as valid, if less intuitive, to say that it preserves left/right and reverses up/down.

We think of it as reversing left/right because in our brains, we are imagining what would be where if instead of looking at a mirror, we had a clone that stepped forward and turned around (rotating from left to right) to face us. Comparing this clone to the mirrored image, we see both have their head at our up and their feet at our down. But looking to our left, we see the left hand of the mirror image but the right hand of the clone. Likewise, looking to our right, we see the right hand of the mirror image but the left hand of the clone. Thus, we interpret the mirror as having reversed left and right from what it would look like if you really stepped forward and turned around.

But now imagine instead that after the clone steps forward, instead of rotating left to right, he does a flip (top to bottom). Now he is once again facing us, but is standing on his head. Now if we compare the clone to the mirrored image, we see that both have their right hand to our right and their left hand to our left. But looking to our up, we see the head of the mirror image but the feet of the clone. Likewise, looking to our down, we see the feet of the mirror image but the feet of the clone. Thus, you could interpret the mirror as having reversed up and down from what it would look like if you really stepped forward and flipped over.

As a second thought experiment, imagine you were laying sideways in front of a mirror, on a couch. Now which axis is being reversed? Left/right? Or up/down? And is that left/right and up/down from your orientation, or the mirror's? Does the mirror even have an inherent up/right and left/down? If not, then how could the mirror "know" which axis to reverse and which to not reverse?

Now, turning around left to right is a much more normal thing for a person to do than flipping over on one's head, so that is the intuitive way we imagine our virtual self turning around to compare to the image we see in the mirror. It's much more natural for us to think of the mirror as reversing left and right, as we spend a lot more of our time turning left and right than we do flipping top to bottom, so our brains are geared for those kind of moves. But in terms of what the mirror is physically doing, it's no more or less valid to say that the mirror reverses up and down. It's all just a matter of how you imagine orienting your virtual self to compare the mirrored image to.

Very interesting on several levels!
I used to be a broadcast television engineer and I would occasionally experiment late at night with the analog color floor cameras by doing things like putting the camera up close to a large video monitor, putting a sheet of text of white paper on the glasses the monitor to set the zoom, gain, white balance and focus, etc, then remove the piece of paper, leaving the camera exactly there focused on the monitor, and then view the resulting image on a second large video monitor after putting it through the video switcher in Master Control.
Sometimes I would use a large mirror in front of the camera, and experiment with lighting using strobes, UV and blacklights, lasers, candles, flashlights, blacklights posters, switcher special effects, music, tones, etc.
While doing this I would leave a local mic on, and record hours of audio and video output from the switcher on 2" reel to reel video tape. I sometimes saw and heard things that made me very uneasy, especially when it was late at night and I was alone, to the extent I became afraid to do it anymore. I should have had a friend like YOU with me...who knows what we might have done and seen? I wish I still had some if those tapes.

Mirrors flip only on one axis, the axis that is directly perpendicular to them. The reason that you see things as flipping left to right, but not top to bottom is because when you write your name on a piece of paper, look at it and then turn it to face the mirror, you turn it as if it were on a merrygoround. If you were to take the same paper and turn it to face the camera as if it were on a ferris wheel, the mirror would appear to flip up and down but not side to side.

Although a common mis-perception, (flat) mirrors do not reverse left-to-right. They reverse front-to-back (only).

If you face north and stand in front of a mirror and place a ruler perpendicularly against the surface of the mirror with the 1 against the mirror and the 12 pointing toward yourself, the image of the ruler in the mirror is reversed front to back. That is the 12 on the real ruler is at South, whereas the 12 on the image of the ruler appears to be at North. This is the same case as in the video with the lettering on the t-shirt despite the clever perspective of the view which tried to support the left-to-right reversal assertion.

If you now place the rule so that the numbered edge lies against the mirror with the 1 at the left, both the real ruler and its image have the 1 at west and the 12 at east.

The reason we think of mirrors as reversing left-to-right is the common experience of viewing written words located behind us through a mirror located in front of us. Such as when looking through the rear-view mirror of a car. The reason things appear reversed in this arrangement is not because of anything the mirror did, but because WE are reversed. If we turn around, we are no longer reversed with respect to the thing being viewed and it appears normal. If a mirror ACTUALLY reversed left-to-right, then when we do an about-face and the mirror also reverses, the sign on the building or car behind us should appear normal (excluding case such as ambulances that have "mirror image" (rofl) lettering, but it does not.

Nope, mirrors do not reverse left to right. That is a common misconception. Mirrors reverse forward to backward. Consider this, take a mirror that looks like it reverses left to right. Now rotate it in its plane by 90 degrees. If the reversal as described was real, it would now reverse top to bottom. But real mirrors don't do that. If a mirror reverses forward to backward then it doesn't matter how it's rotated in the plane. It is transformation invariant. When you move your left hand, the hand that moves is on the left side of the mirror.
We can create a mirror that reverses left and right using a camera and a display. It is very disorientating to see the opposite hand move in a proper left to right reversed display.

Your image in a mirror is not 1/2 real size though because it doesn't really appear AT the surface of the mirror. It appears INSIDE the mirror and the same distance inside as you are outside such that the image is the same size as you really are. That is where your eyes and camera focus to look at the image. The mirror appears half way between you and your image and so the outline of your image at the surface is 1/2 the size.

If you look in a mirror that is one arms length away from you and hold out your arm to touch the mirror, you are clearly two arm lengths away from your image.

The size thing is actually a simple consequence of the fact that the reflection you are seeing seems to come from a source as far from the mirror behind the mirror as you are from the mirror. It's like the difference in perceived size if you move a cup to a distance twice the original distance. It is going to look half the size.
Basically, it doesn't matter too much because you can also perceive depth and can understand the size for what it is.
So for all the people worried, for a perfectly flat mirror you won't perceive yourself as thinner or smaller than you are as long as you are aware that your reflection is some distance behind the mirror.

This is high school physics-
Position of object at infinity- image is inverted and highly diminished
Position behind centre of curvature- image is inverted and slightly diminished
Position at centre of curvature- image is inverted and same sized
Position between centre of curvature and focus- image is inverted and enlarged
Position at focus- image is more enlarged and inverted
Position between focus and pole- image is erect and enlarged

The explanation of why a mirror reverses right and left but not top and bottom is wrong. In fact the mirror does not reverse right and left. To demonstrate this hold out your right hand and touch your mirror and see that the reflection of your right hand in on YOUR right side. Sure, it looks like it is on the mirror image's left side, but it is ACTUALLY ON your right side. Think about it and try it out before you flame me, I'm correct. His explanation of axes is just wrong, because both median(right/left) and transverse (top/bottom) planes are perpendicular to the mirror. The "axis" (plane) that is parallel to the mirror is the frontal (front/back) plane. https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/564x/82/e5/bc/82e5bc2a1c712f56e10dd7ecc4e2d732.jpg

His explanation how mirrors work is wrong: "Mirrors reverse along axes that are perpendicular to them": There is only ONE axis that's perpendicular to a plane (a mirror in this case). And, indeed, a mirror reverses only back and front, not left and right.
If you hold sth. written on a piece of paper in front of you, you can read it left to right (in our culture anyways) and if you intuitively turn it so you can see the writing in the mirror, then you'll see it "mirrored" right to left, sure - but that's only so because you turned the piece of paper around (I assume) along the vertical axis! You could have, instead, turned it around along the horizontal axis, and then the writing would still look left to right in the mirror, but flipped upside down!
Few people know that and, at first, it seems odd. But it's true, mirrors only reverse back and front.

just a note about the apparent reversal of left and right vs the apparent non-reversal of up and down...
Left and right are not reversed... right remains on the right and left remains on the left... up and down also remain in their respective true positions. if you lay down so that you were horizontal, your uppermost shoulder would remain uppermost in the image... if that was your right shoulder, it would remain on the right of the image if you stood up... it is front and back that are reversed. :)

At 03:09 - 03:24 "Mirrors reverse along axes perpendicular to their surfaces, like left and right. They don't also flip things upside down, they don't also reverse up and down, because those directions are parallel to the surface of the mirror."
Left/right and up/down are both parallel to the mirror, only the directions into and out of the mirror are perpendicular. So what's really going on, why is left/right flipped, but not up/down?
When looking in the mirror, you don't actually see left and right flipped. It's when you see other people from the front that you flip left and right, by rotating the other person in the horizontal plane. If you stand behind a person, his left is your left and his right is your right. When he turns around to face you, he switches his left and right: you see the left side of his face on the right, and the right side of his face on the left. This is how other people see you too, they see a rotated version of you. The mirror shows all directions unchanged. Lying down in front of the mirror, or rotating the mirror in its plane, don't change which directions are flipped, since none are.

Oops, around 3:07 your example doesn't seem match what you were explaining, right?
You explained that mirrors reverse along axes that are perpendicular to their surfaces, but not along axes parallel to their surfaces. In your examples, I think you therefore meant to say that a mirror reverses forward/backward, but not up/down or left/right.

As an example, if a mirror is placed in front of me when I'm facing east, my compass and the mirror's compass both unambiguously agree on the direction of north and the north star, since both north and up are parallel to the mirror. On the other hand, though the sun that is setting behind me to the west, the mirrored image appears to be setting in front of me to my east. Left and Right are also perpendicular to the surface of the mirror. Mirrors do not reverse the image left-to-right. They reverse the image's to-and-from aspect. It only seems like your reflection is reversed left-to-right because your mind presupposes that to be looking back at yourself you would need to rotate 180°. Think about it: if you could walk through the mirror to where your reflection is, up would still be up, left would still be left (to the west if you were facing north) but you'd be facing away from the mirror, not toward it. What the mirror reverses is the two and from directions.

The mirror size thing sounds like a bunch of nonsense to me. Of course the trace of your mirror image on the surface of a mirror is always half your size, because the mirror image is always twice as far away as the mirror. Reaching out halfway to an object and tracing its outline will result in a image half the size of the object. That's not very mysterious. It's no different from reaching all the way to the object and tracing it. If i stand right next to a wall and put a coin up to it and trace its outline with a pencil, then take a step back, put that same coin up to the wall (which will look smaller because the coin is now further away from my eyes) and trace its outline again, of course the drawings are gonna be the same size. The coin is still the same!

Angular size changes linearly with distance. Objects have the same size no matter their position. Mystery solved.

Mirrors don't reverse images left and right.  They only reverse images to and from the mirror.  That's why the right side of your body is shown in the right side of the mirror and left side in the left side of the mirror.  If you put a transparent sheet of plastic in front of a mirror and write on it, the words will look the same.  It only looks reversed because you have to turn something around so that it faces the mirror, which is what inverts the image.  Rotate the object to face the mirror in different ways then it will "invert" the image in different ways.

Saying the image on the mirror is "always the same size" is misleading.  As you back away it has a smaller angular size in your eye, making you perceive it as smaller. (The triangles are NOT similar, similar triangles have the same angles)  Really it's no different than backing away from another person, they are always the same height, but you see them shrink.  The only thing unique to the mirror is that your reflection appears twice as far away as the surface of the mirror, so tracing your outline on the mirror gives you a half scale version of yourself.

Watching this I remembered another quite similar question I developed from reading a book about dimensions (I believe by Paul Davies). It goes something like this: Suppose space wraps into itself, like a 3D pacman field, so if you move in a straight (-ish?) line you'd end up in the same place again. Start out with a big space, empty except for you and your little source of light: you would just see yourself in the distance, from the back and upside down (you would see an endless string of yourself if it were not for you blocking the view?). If you'd move towards yourself (with your little jetpack) you would also fly away from yourself so this distance would never change. In the book this hypothetical astronaut has a glowstick in his hand, as he lets go of it he sees himself doing so in the distance. As he flies toward the glowstick in the distance, leaving it behind (the "other" one?!? ;p), he sees himself flying away from it too. When he approaches it and grabs it, he sees himself doing so in the distance and he has gone full circle. All fine? I dunno... Here's some questions: All this time we'd imagine just looking straight forward into ones own back, upside down. But what if we'd look up, we'd see our feet from underneath? And what if we'd look down our feet, would we look ourselves in a bent neck? The same goes for looking to the side and for looking whatever way. So wouldn't you really be seeing yourself everywhere around you, as if you were in the inside of your outsides?!? Now for the bonus horror: Let's shrink this space! Some of you might have seen the 'Portal' set-up with a portal just in front of the subject a a portal just to the back. This person could tap itself on the back, right? Keep this in mind while imagining what would happen with the space-wrapped astronaut if you would shrink his space ever further... WTF right? Would his feet start to touch his head and vice versa, his left side touch his right side, all around himself he would be crushed into himself?!?

There's a misnomer in here. Mirrors don't reverse things left-to-right. Mirrorsreverse things front-to-back. Things look backwards left-to-right because /you/ reverse them that way, when you turn them around to face the mirror. If you turn them to face the mirror by turning them top-over-bottom instead of side-to-side, they'll be upside down in the mirror.

The reason you think it flips left-to-right is because you are doing the flipping when facing something in front of a mirror. When you face text to a mirror, you flip the paper (turn it 180 degrees around the vertical) bringing the text's left side to your right. You could just as easily flip the text 180 degrees around the horizontal, thus leaving it unflipped left-to-right, but rather flipped up-to-down.

At 3:20, totally wrong. Both left/right and top/bottom are parallel to the mirror. The reason we "see" a mirror as left-right flipping but not top-bottom flipping is that it's really in-out flipping, but as we compare the image to ourself, we rotate in the vertical direction, because that's a normal thing to do in a gravity environment, and we also have left-right symmetry. If we instead rotated head-to-toe, we'd see the image as top-bottom flipped, but left-right normal. Classic physics problem and explanation.

Michael I love your videos, they are great! However, I think you made two mistakes in this one. Firstly, left and right is on an axis that is parallel to the mirror, just like up and down. The reason why we only feel left-right is reversed in the mirror is because we define left and right based on up-down and front-back, and front-back is reversed in the mirror. Secondly, the image of an object is not on the mirror, and rather, it is behind the mirror. The size of the image is exactly the same as the object. The half thing you are talking about is more like the size of mirror required to reflect the entire image - it is always the half of the object no matter how far away you are.

Mirrors don't flip things horizontally. How does the mirror know the X direction from the Y direction? It doesn't. You can confirm this by flipping your mirror, (or you) 90 degrees. It flips things in the Z direction.

Things flip inside-out in the Z axis. Picture wearing a glove on your right hand. Point it fingertips first at the mirror. Flip the glove inside out (towards the mirror). It now fits the left hand. Which is your mirror images' left hand.

I have a different theory for why we prefer our mirror-images over photographs: it's not because we're used to our mirrored selves, but because we don't see anything else than the front part of our heads. No one ever sees the back of his head, but he sees that of others all the time. I've learned this when I was in a room that had several mirrors positioned so that I was in fact looking at the side and back and top of my head (depending on which mirror I looked at), and in that moment I experienced myself as if I was looking at someone else: the shape of my head, the twitches I have, the small movements of habit I make, the way my emotions look -- everything was unfamiliar to me. Hence my support of this theory over the simple "it's mirrored, therefore unlikable" theory.

A mirror doesn't flip in the horizontal or vertical direction.

Geometrically, it flips in the depth direction, the direction directly perpendicular, or "normal" to the surface of the mirror.

Imagine you were flattened in the forward direction, until you turned into a flat, 2-D version of your front profile. Now imagine you continued this until you were the same size again, but reversed. That would be how you would look in a mirror.

One way you can tell this is by the fact that, when facing a mirror, your nose points out in front of you as usual, but in your reflection, your nose is pointing the other way: back towards you.

If a mirror flipped only left to right, you would see the back of your head.

It is very likely that Lincon was photographed by Alexander Gardner, who was his official photographer. In those times tintypes were very popular, but a tintype is actually a plate in a camera, meaning that the result is a mirrored image of the real Lincon! In those times they were also doing wet plate collodion negative on glass and then made a positive on albumen print. That would make an image properly faced. Because I'm expert in 19th Century photography (and making youtube videos about it), I must say that the image of a Lincon looks to me more a tintype (or ambrotype) then a print from a collodion negative. Why? Because all the collodion negatives were heavily retouched and this image is not. So the portrait of Lincon is not the best pick to explain the mirroring, because we don't know if we are already looking at the mirrored tintype.
That said, as always thanks for making these videos!

an important thing that i would like to point is out is that a lot of times on the internet i see questions like “ which shows how i really look? the mirror or the photo?”

the answer is THE MIRROR.

The only thing the Mirror does to alter your image is that it is an reflection. However a reflection does not change something that is symmetrical. EX: if you take away the hair of people with an “symmetrical face”  they will look exactly the same in an normal mirror or an “True mirror”.

Now the photo/video is a COMPLETELY  different story.  Your image is being altered COMPLETELY  when you are being videoed or photographed. The end result will depend on if your are photogenic or not. The people who are not photogenic usually end up looking super ugly and an completely different person. 

NOTE: yes the mirror does show your image “unreflected” BUT it completely alters your image while it is doing that. While the mirror does alter your image too, the only thing that it is doing to alter it is creating an an reflection of yourself which does not change how you really look it is only an reflection and as we know reflections do not change the appearance of something that is “symmetrical”.

The explanation of why mirrors "reverse left-to-right" is utter nonsense. Mirrors do no such thing, and the left-right axis is just as parallel to the mirror as the up-down axis. In fact, what is happening is that the mirror is reflecting front-to-back, as one would expect. However, when we see the reflected image of ourselves, we don't imagine it as our face being pulled through the back of our head. Instead, we imagine a person rotated around 180 degrees. Since left and right are described relative to the direction we are facing, we imagine "that person's" left and right as being opposite our own.

Let me put it another way. Imagine I am facing north and looking into a mirror, with my left hand facing west and my right hand facing east, with a ring on my left hand. My reflection in the mirror also has a ring on the hand on the west side. That hasn't changed. However, since the reflection is now facing the opposite direction, we say it is the reflection's "right hand," even though that is still on our left.

Although we don't often think about it this way, we could just as easily say that mirrors "reverse up and down" rather than left and right, in the following sense: Instead of imagining the reflection to be a person rotated 180 degrees standing on the floor, imagine it flipping 180 degrees head-over-heels. Now instead of the ring seemingly being on the right hand instead of the left hand, we have the head seemingly being on the bottom half of the body instead of the top half of the body. Clearly the mirror has reversed up and down! The only reason we don't usually think about it that way is because we are bilaterally symmetric, so one type of rotation looks "almost right" (minus the ring being on the wrong side), while the other looks completely wrong.

Your bathroom mirror experiment is only valid in a closed or isolated system.
It is not one's perspective that counts, but the system's perspective, and whether one is inside of it or outside of it (an open system would do), where in either case the results would be the opposite of each other between what a closed and an open system would show or produce.

 We would need a tertiary point of view as well, and nothing could  be proclaimed or any real scientific data obtained by one or two observers only.

Two factual statements that are flat-out wrong in this video:

1. That mirrors revert left to right. No, they don't. Mirrors revert front and back, and this reversal combined with the left-right symmetry of the human body makes us think that mirrors flip things left to right.

2. That the image formed by a flat mirror is half of the actual size of the object. No, it's not. It would be half if you thought the image was in the mirror's plane, but it isn't. The image is in fact on the other side of the mirror, at the same distance as the object, and it has the same size as the object.

He is mistaken about why a mirror "reverses left to right and not up and down." A mirror reverses front to back. We typically mentally model that as stepping around to that position. When we are (mentally) standing where we perceive our reflection, we perceive that our right and left sides are flipped. If you instead consider doing a flip to get to that position, viola, right and left are fine but it was top and bottom that were reversed!

I think the reason people often say mirrors flip left and right is a result of the way we tell whether two things are are the same, which we would say has a 'left' and 'right' and can already visualize in 3D:

First by whether it looks the same if it were brought to the same location.
Next by if it looks the same if it were brought to the same location and rotated about it's vertical axis.
Finally by if it looks the same if it were brought to the same location, rotated about it's vertical axis and then rotated about some other axis.

We consider these objects to be the same because, as we walk past a stationary object, the 'right' of it might become the 'left' of it and it might go from being 'near' to being 'far' but it's 'top' always stays it's 'top'. The reason we might check transformation in that order is to save thinking time/effort: Only when such an object topples will it's 'top' change.

So when a person sees an object in the mirror that they identify with an object in the room they stand in, they first mentally move it without rotating it. Where that fails they rotate it around the vertical axis. When this makes an object that isn't symmetrical about left and right, but is otherwise the same the conclusion is that the object isn't 'the same' unless the mirror has exchanged these two directions and the thought process ends there. In fact, this effect of switching directions is nothing special about left and right: The only reason left and right were flipped this time was because the person chose to rotate the object about the vertical axis first. You have only to rotate the object about it's horizontal axis instead to see that up and down would be reversed and left and right would be preserved.

So really the problem begins as soon as the person interprets the objects they see in the mirror as the result of a translation, a rotation about the vertical axis and finally a reflection. In fact the simplest way to transform their world into the reflected one is to exchange forwards and backwards, which is an unnatural way to identify objects for the brains of humans.
Mirrors do not flip left to right. They flip front to back.

I believe your explanation of up/down versus left/right, mirror non-reversal versus reversal, is wrong. You could have portrayed the up/down axis just the same way as you portrayed the left/right axis, that is, with a perpendicular hand.

I believe the correct explanation is that right/left is a different kind of direction axis from up/down, north/south, east/west or any direction system which is rigidly fastened to the coordinate system of the mirror, the floor, the walls.

The left/right direction system, on the other hand, is fastened to the observer! If I turn around 180 degrees in place, keeping my feet on the floor, suddenly my own left/right directions are exactly reversed. By contrast, no matter how I turn around or move my body, north/south, east/west and up/down stay exactly as they were.

Actually, mirrors do NOT flip the horizontal; but our brains think they do because of our perspective. 

Everyone knows the 'backward mirror text' trick, but for a unique spin on it, grab a semi-transparent bag or something else with writing on it that you can see from both sides. Hold it up to the mirror like you normally would, and it's reflection will appear reversed, but if you look through the transparent material, it will ALSO appear reversed.

You see, when we turn a page away from us, we are flipping it already, and since we need text facing away from us to see it in the mirror, well we wind up flipping it and SURPRISE! It's backward in the mirror; except it's not the mirror that's doing the flipping, we've flipped it ourselves to show it in the mirror. Try it and find out, it's mindblowing.

Left-right is parallel to the surface of the mirror when you stand in front of it, so it's not reversed. Your left hand appears to your left in the mirror. The only direction that isn't parallel to the mirror surface is forwards-backwards, and that is the only direction being reversed. Your nose is pointing forwards in reality, but it points back to you in the mirror. The problem is that you EXPECT it to be reversed in two dimensions rather than just one. If someone stands in front of you, perfectly aligned to your directions, and then turns around to face you, they will have turned in both the forwards-backwards direction and the left-right direction. Their left hand will be to your right. That is how your brain expects something to look in a mirror, and that is how you appear to them.

Why do you say that up and down is parallel to the mirror surface and left and right is perpendicular?  That does not seem right?  The mirror does not flip anything.  It faithfully reflects what is put in front of it.  The only flipping that happens is when you turn your head to look at the object.  Because we turn our heads around to the left or the right instead of up or down, we see the object reversed left to right instead of up and down.

Another reason people may like they way they look in a mirror and not in photos could be due to focal length. The focal length of the eye may differ from a camera thus morphing the face in unpredictable ways. For example, in portrait photography the common practice is to photograph a person using a 50mm or 85mm prime lens on a full frame camera standing a number of feet from the person. If you use a wide angle lens standing close to a person then this will literally flatten and distort the face, making the nose look really big relative to the rest of the face. A lot of people who like the way they look in the mirror but not in photos tend to take self portraits, and often times do so using a wide angle lens an arms length away, so their face gets distorted and they end up perplexed as to why they look horrible in the photograph and not in the mirror.

Left and right are just as parallel to the surface of the mirror as up and down. Neither set is flipped.

If you look at yourself in a mirror, your left hand is to your left, your right hand is too your right, the top of your head is up and the bottom of your head is down.

What gets flipped is front to back, which is why circularly polarised light switches, and the real reason your image is "flipped".

The easiest way to see this is to use thin paper or something clear. Write something on the front. Looking at the front in the mirror produces the same "mirrored" text as looking at it from the back.

So what you see when you look in a mirror is not something that is flipped from left to right, it is flipped from front to back.

Well, part of why people prefer themselves in a mirror than in a picture also has to do with the way the image appears. Mirrors simulate depth whereas photographs do not. A photo is flat thus the image is flattened which distorts the final image. Mirrors, on the other hand, look much more like what we see in real life, just flipped. When people say "the camera adds [insert multiple of 10 here] pounds," it's sorta true. Since the image in the photo is flattened, it turns our natural curvature into a single plane and it makes people appear fatter than they really are. I think that probably has a lot to do with it as well.

In 11,720 comments, I assume that this has already been mentioned.  The comments starting at about 3:07 are not correct.  A flat mirror does not "flip" the image left to right. It is correct that the axis which is reversed is perpendicular, but this is the axis into or out of the mirror, not the left/right axis.

He was talking about your own reflection and how you perceive it. Not the objects behind you.

Take a look at his diagram at 5:04.  From the properties of reflection we know that the incident and reflective angles of light on a mirror are equal.  If we apply some basic geometry we can then come up with the equation Hi (height of image on mirror) = Ho(height of object) * Ro / (Ro + Rd).  So, if Ro = Rd as in the example of looking at yourself in the mirror, then Hi will equal Ho * 1/2.  Draw some pictures and see if you can duplicate that equation. :)

The pattern he is talking about only works if the ratio of the distance from the mirror to the object, Rd (your body), and the distance from the mirror to the observer, Ro (your eyes) is constant.  In the example of looking at yourself in the mirror this ratio, Rd/Ro is 1, a constant, as both your eyes and body are the same distance from the mirror.

However in your example Rd is a constant since the pattern behind you isn't moving, but Ro will change as you move, so the ratio will also change.

@3:18 this is a common misconception: mirrors don't reverse left and right any more than they reverse up and down. It's just that you imagine yourself walking to the other side of the mirror (rotating yourself around a vertical axis) and compare those two to see a "left-right flipped" image. You don't imagine jumping into a handstand on the far side, rotating yourself around a horizontal axis. That would leave your left on the left and your right on the right, but "flip" your uo and down!

Rejoice! His mirror vs camera explanation is wrong. One can easily see that left-right is parallel to the mirror just like up-down. It's the camera that's lying to you.

Cameras make you look fatter because of barrel distortion introduced by the camera's convex lens, especially true of smartphone cameras. 

Also, in most camera shots, you are lit from the front, which causes a harsh image. In a mirror, and in professional studios, you are mostly lit from the back, which creates a softer image.

Your explanation about images being reversed in mirrors having to do with parallel vs perpendicular is incorrect. In reality, it's not reversed - what's on the left is still on the left, and what's on the right is still on the right. They appear reversed due to our eyes being separated horizontally, and the way our brain processes visual input to determine depth.

Quick note: if you dislike photos of yourself, it's more likely because the convex lens of the camera distorts reality. The more convex the lens; the bigger the size of the image> the greater the distortion. If you take a photo 50cm from your face, you can't see your ears on the photo. If you take a picture from 5m away, you can clearly see your ears (and the picture is much closer to how you look in reality). 
Try it out and see if yourselves. It's an eye opener.

...you see the word "POTS", with backwards P and S.  If you look at the (now) back of the paper in front of you at this point, it will ALSO say POTS (with backwards P and S).  So the left side of your paper image hits the left side of the mirror and bounces back to your eye, just like the right side hit the right side of the mirror... and the top hit the top of the mirror, and the bottom hit the bottom. Nothing is "flipped" except the object. Has nothing to do with the geometry of your eyes.

You're right, Carl.  Mirrors don't flip anything. I think the very powerful pull to interpret mirror images as 'flipping' left and right is really an optical illusion, based on the strong symmetry of the human body.
I think I would go crazy if I was subjected to a spherical mirror.

Real life is flipped. Mirrors don't flip things at all (except the depth). It's like standing behind someone: their left hand will be on the left, their right hand will be on the right, and their head will be at the top - no flipping. But normally to see someone's face, they have to turn around. There are two ways they can turn around: by turning horizontally like normal, or by doing a back-flip hand-stand. If they do a handstand they are flipped vertically but not horizontally.
Left and right are just as parallel to the mirror as up and down are. A better explanation of why mirrors seem to flip things horizontally is given by Richard Feynman here: /watch?v=msN87y-iEx0
At arm's length, it's about the size of an ordinary pea.  Very counter-intuitive!

Vsauce, You may have been duped by the trickery of mirrors. Stand in front of a large mirror and have a friend lay on a side and facing the mirror. YOUR left-right is flipped but not your friend's up-down even though they are oriented the same way in space; your friend's left-right is flipped but not your up--down. How does the mirror know what to flip? It doesn't flip anything. This is an illusion based on the symmetry of our bodies. In a mirror you see a mirror image, not a 'flipped' image.

Up and down are just as parallel to the surface of a flat mirror as left and right.  That explanation is pure nonsense.

Mirrors do not flip left and right at all.  They flip front and back.  When you look at something in a mirror, you're looking at its front surface as if it were otherwise entirely transparent and you viewed it from the back.

Sticking the camera at the focal point of the cylinder does flip the image.  Doing the same with a spherical mirror would also flip up and down.

Explanation for mirror images at 3.20 is incorrect. A mirror image is an inversion along any axis, but the human perception is that to view the image, you would naturally turn 180 around Y-axis, since we have a strong symmetry along the X-axis. But if you were to turn 180 degrees along any other axis (say X) you would see the image inverse perpendicular to this axis. There is no 'turning' in a mirror image, only a depth inversion.

Deja-vu is when your mind sees something so much it becomes odd to it. Example, saying the word 'word' a bunch of times starts to confuse you. Is word even a word? Am I saying it correctly? Stuff like that.

When this happens in the real world, you mind tries to figure out memories that would fill in our expectation on what's happening and it causes deja-vu. 

It's essentially, you've seen this so much that your brain predicts what will happen.

Your home router currently has an IPv4 address (kind of like a phone number). Currently IPv4 supports 4.3 billion addresses. 

With IPv6 there will be 300 billion billion billion billion usable addresses, which should be enough for a very, very long time, if not forever.

The Internet won't "run out of space" anytime soon. The only limitation would be physical space for servers and computers, but as technology keeps improving more space can be crammed into hard drives and flash drives.

Actually, I'm pretty sure that you would see just a mirrored sphere. Half-silvered mirrors reflect based on the relative amount of light striking either side. In other words, you can only see through a half-silvered mirror if you're on the side of the mirror that's darker. Being on the outside of a half-silvered sphere with the light source on the same side, the sphere would appear completely reflective. Only if the light source were inside would you be able to see a reflective hemisphere.

Because a mirror isn't a picture.  The objects behind you, when viewed in the mirror, are effectively as far away from you as they actually are, plus twice the distance from you to the mirror.  It's the visual distance that matters.

It may help to think about it like this: if you approach a plate glass wall without your glasses so that a sticker on the wall is in focus, the objects beyond the wall are still whatever distance away.  It probably doesn't surprise you they're not in focus.

Assuming the light was coming from the space inside the mirror (Let's pretend that there's no air, because the mirror would reflect that too, (to a degree)) what you would see would be the color of the light. So, say it was white, you would see white, green, you would see green.

When you speak, you're not only hearing the sound as it exits your mouth, travels through the air and enters your ear, making the eardrums vibrate; you're also hearing all the internal vibrations within your bones due to vibrations of your vocal cords (Which is why you still hear yourself when you cover your ears).

When you hear yourself recorded, you're only hearing your voice as pure sound, without any of the internal vibration. It sounds weird because you're not used to it.

I actually know this one. It's because when we speak, our voice echoes and reverberates throughout our own head , and our chests as well, changing the way we hear it. Essentially, we are hearing it with the inside of our ears. When the sound of our voice is captured with an audio recorder and played back to us, we hear only what comes out of our mouths, and we hear it the way we hear everything else.

The entire part about how you look smaller in a mirror explains that.  The image you see in the mirror in your car is smaller than what you would see by actually observing from that point, and therefore it appears to be farther away.  if you were standing in your house and saw somebody behind you in a mirror, you would most likely perceive them to be farther away than they actually are, and when you turn around, you might be surprised at how close they are.

If you have a second mirror you can bend the angle, and see what everone else can see.
But no one can see you the way you see yourself.

False. It's because left and right are not the same idea as up and down. If you're facing north, and the mirror is in front of you, then if you point east, west, up or down (parallel to the mirror) so does your reflection. but if you point forward (north), your reflection points backwards (south). This reverses our left and right, because we define left by which direction we are facing, but we define up as "away from earth".

The "size" of image "from your perspective" is measured by the angle (or solid angle) subtended by the image over the coordinate space centered at your eye. This does indeed change as you move closer or farther from a mirror, and is the same as if the object were at a distance of d(you_to_mirror) + d(mirror_to_object).
The object is only half size from the perspective of the *mirror*.

Left and right are also parallel to the surface of the mirror, but a mirror doesn't actually change left and right. Look at the writing on a shirt, and look at the shapes of the letters. The left side as you look down at your shirt is also the left side when you look at the mirror.
A mirror actually flips the front-to-back axis, which changes the "handedness" of the coordinate system. In effect, it changes clockwise writing motions to counterclockwise—and vice versa.

Add in the effects of dopamine and you're exactly right. Our bodies adapted to send dopamine throughout the brain to reward us for finding these scarce building blocks of energy, and effectively, life.  It's not only so that we eat every bit of it because we actually enjoyed eating it, but the dopamine is also giving us a reward (a good feeling, a 'natural high') and as a result we feel inclined to find more of those essential nutrients, and hunt for them harder.

But then there is also things that just have a protection mechanism to prevent being eaten so they can create offspring.  These things usually taste bad for most creatures, but through experimentation and unfortunate deaths before science caught up with our curiosity, people eventually realized that even things that tasted bad were actually pretty damn healthy.
These days things are tested rigorously in labs to ensure safety and then get whitelisted, especially fungi, bacteria and similar.

High energy food, such as fatty and sweet foods, give us very much energy for little effort, thus we are sort of hardwired to prefer that food type. Before agriculture, fatty and sweet foods was very scarce so it was very beneficial to eat these food when they where available in the hunter/gatherer society. Now that fatty and sweet food is in over abundance we are raised eating lots and lots of that and thus come to grow used to eating only that so the other foods are not as attractive to us.

I think I can have a go answering that. Our taste buds are tuned to like what IS good for us. You have to remember that when we were hunter/gatherers (and for a large proportion of our existence we have been) salt, sugar and fatty foods were rare, so we'd only consume them in small portions. In small portions, sugary foods for example, provide loads of energy which for a hunter is very useful (as it's more a more efficient source of energy than eating bread).

Basically the human eye doesn't see a number of static "frames" per second. The human eye continuously streams data to the brain.

Generally the brain holds the image in memory for 1/15 of a second, so anything above 15 FPS appears smooth. Most movies and videos are recorded at 24 FPS, and most screens operate at 60 hz.. 
Personally, I can tell the difference between playing a game at 60 FPS vs 120 FPS..

mirrors aren't flipped left right, when you look at a mirror, things on your right appear on the right had side of the mirror.  The reason that it seems flipped is because near and far(front and back) are flipped and your brain assumes the only way to do that is to rotate left or right 180 degrees.  It is like reading an overhead projector slide from the far side instead of the front, because of the front back reversal.  If it was flipped left and right, you couldn't high five yourself.

Why mirrors invert left for right, but not up for down has to do with what we are used to. In fact mirrors do not invert in either direction. It looks like that to us, because we are azimuthally symmetric. When we walk over to the other side and look back we do so by turning in azimuth. If we were non-symmetric weightless space creatures we would not be obligated to walk around in azimuth. If we got used to flipping over we would ask why do we change around left for right but not up for down.

The left and right directions are also parallel to the mirrors surface. The perpendicular axis he talks about is actually back to front, not left to right. The reason we perceive the image of ourselves to be flipped, is because we need to turn around our vertical axis in order to see ourselves in the mirror. The vertical axis is defined by that movement. The same goes for any object we put in front of a mirror. The image appears to be flipped like this due to way we present it to the mirror.

Check the fixed velocity equation in that video again, but sub in c for both V1 and V2. You'll find that to a fixed observer, both trains are moving at the same speed, c. There is only a tiny difference at speeds like 2mph - when things get fast, there is a much larger effect on the combined velocity.

If you have a train moving the speed of light inside of another train moving the speed of light then you would think that the inside train would travel twice the speed of light. That would be true if the equation for velocity w of the object in the train were w = u + v, but it is actually w = (u + v)/(1 + uv/c²). With c being the speed of light. The equation actually works out to (c + c)/(1 + c²/c²) = 2c/2 = c. So the inside train would only be traveling the speed of light and no faster.

first of all, only particles without mass (like photons) can move with lightspeed (in fact, they can not move any slower). Thus a train made from physical matter would move slower that the speed of light. The addition of speed would reduce the closer you get to the speed of light, so if you have two trains moving with 99% the speed of light, the resulting speed might be something like 99.99%. No particle will ever reach 100% speed of light under normal circumstances, no matter what POV is used.

Actually, fuck it. This is going to be a horribly oversimplified answer, but whatever.
Any physicist can tell you that as a system accelerates toward the speed of light, the passage of time slows down within that system. It actually slows down at exactly the correct rate so that moving at the speed of light within the system is the same as moving at the speed of light outside the system. As such, at the speed of light time ceases to pass at all. The second train couldn't be moving.

That is an interesting question! I had a think about it, and I *think* I know the answer: First of all, we need to assume the first train has no mass. Otherwise the first train would gain infinite mass. So, then we put the second train in the first train. We power up the second train, which also has no mass, what we would see is the second train would be STILL relative to the first. This is because anything with/without mass will stop accelerating at the speed of light (186,000 miles/second).

Contrary to popular belief, velocities don't just sum up. 
Use this formula to calculate what speed you will observe:

V(observed) = (v1+v2) : (1+v1*v1/c^2)
v1=v2=c
So you have:

2c : (1+c^2/c^2) = 2c:2= c
So you would see both moving at the speed of light.

Hey Michael, here is another interesting bit about mirrors. If you place a parabolic mirror on top of another parabolic mirror so that the reflective sides are facing each other, cut a (small) hole in the top of the one on top, and finally place a small object inside the 2, you will see the object hovering above the hole. This is because, by definition, light that hits any point on a parabola will always come back to meet at the same location.

One way mirrors don't actually exist. "One way mirrors" are actually just mirrors which let a little bit of light pass through from either side. For example, a mirror in an interrogation room only lets you look through on one side because the light is bright on that side, so the people in the other room can see the light that passes through, but there's not enough light coming from the dimmer room to let the interrogatee see them. If the both rooms are lit up, the mirror acts just like a window.

Could you in a future video explain in more detail why mirrors act the way they do in terms of flipping or not flipping and image. I think there can be a lot of things you could discuss along with QED. Just a suggestion, for you to mull over.

The light particles are dispersed through refraction. This leads to a bounce back effect. A mirror allows 99.9% to bounce back to where you can see, the last bit of light is absorbed by the material of the mirror. He touches on this concept in the video, but to make it even easier to under stand look at it this way. 

(throwing a fruit against a wall, most will splatter back, but a little will be stuck to the wall) The percentage of light absorbed is the "fruit" that is stuck on the wall.

You and your reflection are both the same size—the light from your feet is still COMING from where your feet are—but because of the angles at which the light has to travel to get to your eyes, the light from your feet bounces off of the mirror at exactly halfway between there and your eyes, so from your perspective, the two-dimesional image on the surface of the mirror itself is actually half of what it appears to be.

A mirror does NOT reverse left to right.  It doesn't reverse anything.  It appears to reverse because what you are actually experiencing is a change in the observer.  When you look at a mirror, you are the observer.  However, when someone else looks at you head on, they are rotated 180 degrees.  This is what appears to reverse left and right.  If the observer stood on his head, you would appear to be upside down from his point of view.  In that case you could argue the mirror flips up and down.
But your hand wont touch the mirror though.

The image is half of the original size from your perspective. When you get too close to a mirror it becomes difficult to see your entire reflection because your eyes don't have a large enough field of vision (they're too close the image) so you tend to imagine what the image would look like to a third party observer (your mind fills in the gaps) which makes your reflection a different size (because you're not viewing it). If you actually try getting as close as possible and mark it, it works.
